title: Attack
subtitle: Melee or ranged attack
description: Perform a melee or ranged attack with a weapon, or make an Unarmed Strike. This is the most common action to take in combat.
bullets: Certain features, such as the Warrior's Extra Attack, allow you to make more than one attack with this single action. Each attack is a separate roll and can target different creatures. You can also move between these attacks.
Unarmed Strike: You can make a special melee attack to Grapple, Shove, or deal damage. To deal damage, make a melee attack roll. On a hit, it deals 1 + your Strength modifier bludgeoning damage.
Weapon Mastery: When you attack with a weapon, you can apply a special Mastery property (like Push, Slow, or Topple) if you are a Warrior or have the Weapon Master feat.

Two-Weapon Fighting: The Nick weapon property (on Scimitars, Light Hammers, etc.) allows you to make an extra attack with that weapon as part of this action (no bonus action required), but you don't add your ability modifier to the damage.
Advantage Sources: Attacking a Blinded, Paralyzed, Petrified, Restrained, Stunned, or Unconscious target. Melee attacks against a Prone target. Attacking while you are Invisible.
Disadvantage Sources: Attacking while you are Blinded, Frightened, Poisoned, or Restrained. Ranged attacks against a Prone target. Attacking a target that is Invisible.

title: Cast a Spell
subtitle: Cast time of 1 action
description: Cast a spell with a casting time of 1 action.
bullets: Bonus Action Spell Rule: The only rule limiting the number of spells per turn is this: If you cast any spell as a Bonus Action, the only other spell you can cast that turn is a cantrip with a 1-Action casting time.
There is no general rule against casting two leveled spells in one turn (e.g., using Action Surge).

Concentration: Many spells require concentration. You lose concentration if you: cast another spell that requires concentration, take damage (requiring a CON save vs. DC 10 or half the damage taken), are Incapacitated, or die.

title: Dash
subtitle: Double movement speed
description: Gain extra movement for the current turn equal to your speed after applying any modifiers.
bullets: For example, if your speed is 30 feet, using the Dash action gives you an additional 30 feet of movement for the turn, for a total of 60 feet.
This movement is subject to all normal rules and can provoke opportunity attacks.

title: Disarm
subtitle: Knock item from enemy's grasp
description: Attempt to knock an item from a creature's grasp.
bullets: This was an optional rule in the 2014 DMG, now a standard action.
You use one of your attacks from the Attack action to make a special check.
You make a Strength (Athletics) check contested by the target's Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check (target's choice).
If you win, your attack deals no damage, but the target drops one item of your choice that it is holding.
The target has advantage on its check if it is holding the item with two or more hands.

title: Disengage
subtitle: Prevent opportunity attacks
description: For the rest of your turn, your movement doesn't provoke opportunity attacks.
bullets: This is the primary way to safely move out of an enemy's reach in melee.
The benefit lasts only until the end of the current turn.

title: Dodge
subtitle: Increase defenses
description: Focus entirely on avoiding attacks, making you a much harder target to hit.
bullets: Until the start of your next turn, any attack roll made against you has disadvantage if you can see the attacker.
You also make Dexterity saving throws with advantage.
You lose this benefit if you are Incapacitated or if your speed drops to 0.

title: Don/Doff a Shield
subtitle: Equip or unequip a shield
description: It takes one action to equip or unequip a shield.
bullets: This is a specific use of the Use an Object action. Unlike armor, which takes several minutes to don or doff, a shield can be equipped or removed in the midst of combat.

title: Escape
subtitle: Escape a grapple or restraint
description: Attempt to free yourself from a grapple or a similar effect.
bullets: To escape a grapple, you use your action to make a Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check (your choice) against the effect's escape DC.
For a grapple initiated by a creature, the DC is that creature's grapple DC (8 + STR mod + Prof Bonus).
This action can also be used for other effects that specify an escape, like being caught in a net.

title: Grapple
subtitle: Special unarmed strike
description: Attempt to seize a creature and hold it in place. This now forces a saving throw instead of a contested check.
bullets: This replaces one of your attacks when you take the Attack action. You need at least one free hand.
The target must be no more than one size larger than you and must be within your reach.
The target must make a Strength saving throw (DC = 8 + your Strength modifier + your proficiency bonus).

Probability: A fixed DC makes success more predictable. A level 5 Barbarian with 18 STR (+4) has a Grapple DC of 15. A creature with a +2 STR save must roll a 13 or higher, giving the Barbarian a 60% chance of success.
On a failed save, the target gains the Grappled condition (its speed becomes 0). The condition ends if you become Incapacitated or if the target uses its action to Escape.

title: Help
subtitle: Grant an ally advantage
description: You can lend your aid to another creature, making their task easier or distracting a foe.
bullets: Aid an Ability Check: You help another creature with a d20 Test. They gain advantage on the next ability check they make, provided they make it before the start of your next turn.

Distract an Enemy: Alternatively, you can aid an ally in attacking a creature within 5 feet of you. You feint or otherwise distract the target. The next attack roll from an ally against that target has advantage, provided the attack occurs before the start of your next turn.

title: Hide
subtitle: Attempt to hide
description: Attempt to become unseen and unheard. The mechanics for this have been standardized.
bullets: You must be heavily obscured or behind at least three-quarters cover to attempt to hide.
Make a DC 15 Dexterity (Stealth) check. You cannot hide from a creature that can see you.
On a success, you gain the Invisible condition relative to other creatures. Make a note of your check's total.
A creature can use the Search action to make a Wisdom (Perception) check against your Stealth check's total to find you.
The Invisible condition ends if you make a sound louder than a whisper, make an attack roll, cast a spell with a verbal component, or are no longer obscured/behind cover.

title: Improvise
subtitle: Any action not on this list
description: Perform any action you can imagine that isn't covered by the other actions.
bullets: When you describe an action not detailed elsewhere, the DM tells you whether it's possible and what kind of d20 Test, if any, you need to make to determine success or failure.

title: Influence
subtitle: Socially affect a creature
description: Attempt to socially influence a creature, even during combat.
bullets: As an action, you can try to influence a creature you can communicate with.
Make a Charisma check using Deception, Intimidation, or Persuasion. The DM might have you contest this with the creature's Wisdom (Insight) check.
The creature's attitude (Friendly, Indifferent, Hostile) can affect the DC.
A success can cause a temporary behavioral shift, such as getting a hostile creature to pause and listen, but it does not impose a condition like Charmed or Frightened.

title: Ready
subtitle: Choose trigger and action
description: Prepare to act in response to a specific, perceivable trigger.
bullets: First, define a perceivable trigger (e.g., 'When an enemy opens the door').
Then, choose the action you will take in response (e.g., 'I'll cast Fire Bolt at it') or choose to move up to your speed.
When the trigger occurs, you can use your reaction to perform the readied action. This happens immediately after the trigger is complete.
If you ready a spell, you cast it on your turn but hold its energy, which requires concentration. If your concentration is broken, the spell and spell slot are lost.

title: Search
subtitle: Attempt to find something
description: Devote your attention to finding something that is hidden or not obvious.
bullets: You make a Wisdom (Perception) check to find a hidden creature or object.
You make an Intelligence (Investigation) check to find clues that suggest a hidden object's presence or to deduce how a trap works.
The DM may call for other checks, such as Wisdom (Survival) to find tracks.

title: Shove
subtitle: Special unarmed strike
description: Attempt to knock a creature prone or push it 5 feet away from you. This now forces a saving throw.
bullets: This replaces one of your attacks when you take the Attack action. The target must be no more than one size larger than you and within your reach.
The target must make a Strength saving throw (DC = 8 + your Strength modifier + your proficiency bonus).

Probability: Like Grapple, the fixed DC provides consistent odds. A Fighter with 16 STR (+3) at level 1 has a Shove DC of 13. A goblin with a +0 STR save fails on a roll of 12 or lower (60% success rate for the Fighter).
On a failed save, you choose one of two effects: either you knock the target Prone, or you push it 5 feet directly away from you.
The Push Weapon Mastery property provides a similar effect without replacing an attack.

title: Stabilize a Creature
subtitle: Aid a dying creature
description: Stop a dying creature from needing to make death saving throws.
bullets: You use your action to administer first aid to an unconscious creature at 0 hit points.
Make a DC 10 Wisdom (Medicine) check. A Healer's Kit allows you to automatically succeed.
On a success, the creature becomes stable. It is no longer dying but remains unconscious at 0 HP. A stable creature regains 1 hit point after 1d4 hours.

title: Study
subtitle: Learn about a creature
description: Observe a creature to learn useful information about it.
bullets: Choose a creature you can see or hear and make an Intelligence check using a skill related to the creature's type (e.g., Arcana for constructs, Nature for beasts, Religion for undead).
The DC is 10 + the creature's Challenge Rating (minimum 1).
On a success, you learn one of the following about the target: its Armor Class, its Speed, its highest or lowest ability score, or one of its damage resistances, immunities, or vulnerabilities.

title: Use an Object
subtitle: Interact, use special abilities
description: Interact with an object or use an object that requires an action.
bullets: You get one free 'object interaction' on your turn (drawing a weapon, opening a door, etc.). This action is used for more complex interactions.
This action is used to activate special items, such as drinking a potion, using alchemist's fire, or activating certain magic items.

title: Use class feature
subtitle: Some features use actions
description: Use a racial or class feature that uses an action
reference: See class page for more information.

title: Climb onto a Bigger Creature*
subtitle: Climb a larger foe
description: A large opponent can be treated as terrain for the purpose of climbing onto it.
bullets: (Optional Rule – DMG):
As an action, a creature can make a Strength (Athletics) check to climb onto a creature at least two sizes larger.
The DC is the target creature's Fortitude DC.
On a success, the climber moves into the target's space and clings to it. The climber moves with the target.
The climber has Advantage on attack rolls against the creature it is climbing on.
The larger creature can use its action to make a Strength (Athletics) check against the climber's Fortitude DC to dislodge them.

title: Administer Potion **
subtitle: Use a potion on another
description: A common homebrew that splits the action economy of potion use.
bullets: This homebrew adapts to the common 'bonus action to drink' rule.
Drinking a Potion (Self): Use a bonus action.
Administering a Potion (Other): Use a full action. This involves retrieving the potion, moving to the ally, and carefully administering it, justifying the longer time cost.

title: Called Shot **
subtitle: Target a specific body part
description: A common house rule to allow targeting specific parts of an enemy for an added effect, at the cost of accuracy.
bullets: (Common Homebrew Rule):
This remains a popular homebrew option. The 2024 rules still assume attacks target vital areas generally.
As an action, declare a 'called shot' and take a penalty to your attack roll (typically -5).
On a hit, you apply an additional effect based on the location targeted:
Head: Impose the Dazed condition until the end of its next turn.
Arm/Hand: Force the target to drop one held item.
Leg/Foot: Impose the Slowed condition until the end of its next turn.
Eye: Impose the Blinded condition for 1 round (often requires a higher penalty, like -10).
